title: Installing posh-git - A PowerShell Environment for Git
summary: In this post, I detail the basic steps to install posh-git, a powershell module that integrates git into PowerShell. This makes it easier to work with git from any PowerShell session.
body:
posh-git is a PowerShell module that integrates Git features directly in PowerShell. It includes inline status, color coded text, tab completion for common git commands and branch names, and more. It is a useful command line tool for working with Git on windows. The installation below assumes that you have PsGet installed.

Open a new PowerShell session and run Install-Module posh-git. You might get a NuGet prompt for accepting packages, choose yes or "Y" for this. You also may get a prompt to trust installing packages from the the PowerShell gallery, choose Yes or "Y" for this too. Once it is installed, you can use it by running Import-Module posh-git. To see it work, navigate to a git repository in PowerShell. You should see something similar to this.



To avoid having to enter Import-Module posh-git into every new PowerShell session, you can add it to the PowerShell settings to be loaded automatically. To add it to the current user, current PowerShell host settings execute the command Add-PoshGitToProfile. To see what it did run notepad $profile.CurrentUserCurrentHost. This will bring up Notepad with the configuration file. It should contain the line Import-Module posh-git. This means anytime a new PowerShell session is opened, the module will be imported automatically so git integration will "just work".

That is it for getting posh-git installed and usable in PowerShell. The readme on GitHub explains how to add it across hosts and more configuration options for customizing the prompt.
